<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Add:
```c
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtList_Add:
UtListNode_t *UtList_NewNode(void *Data, uint32 DataSize)
{
    union NodeAllocator
    {
        UtListNode_t Node;
        double       AlignDbl;
        void *       AlignPtr;
        long         AlignLong;
    } * AllocNode;

    AllocNode = malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize);
    memset(AllocNode, 0, sizeof(union NodeAllocator));
    AllocNode->Node.Data     = &AllocNode[1];
    AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
    memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);

    AllocNode->Node.Next = &AllocNode->Node;
    AllocNode->Node.Prev = &AllocNode->Node;

    return &AllocNode->Node;
}
...
void UtList_Insert_Before(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode, UtListNode_t *NewNode)
{
    NewNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    NewNode->Prev       = ExistingNode->Prev;
    NewNode->Prev->Next = NewNode;
    NewNode->Next->Prev = NewNode;
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetHead(UtListHead_t *ListHead, uint32 Tag)
{
    if (Tag >= ListHead->NumberOfTags)
    {
        return NULL;
    }
    return &ListHead->Tags[Tag];
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The assignment AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize; by itself does not use any <string.h> functions and therefore does not directly violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. However, the surrounding code uses memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize). That memcpy would violate Rule 21.17 if DataSize exceeds the actual destination or source buffer size — for example if sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize overflows (leading to an allocation smaller than DataSize), if malloc returns NULL, or if the caller's Data buffer is smaller than DataSize. In those cases the memcpy would access beyond object bounds.
